Binomial Nomenclature rules
  • All names are in {{c1::Latin}} or resemble it
  • Printed names are {{c2::italicised}}
  • Handwritten names are {{c3::separately underlined}}
  • First name is {{c4::Genus}} and Second name is {{c4::Species}}
  • Generic epithet starts with a {{c5::Capital}} letter and Specific epithet starts with a {{c5::small}} letter
  • Name of author comes after {{c6::Specific epithet}}
Group of individual organisms with fundamental similarities

Herbarium

  • Contains {{c1::dried, pressed and preserved}} {{c2::plant}} specimens
  • Also have following information:
    • {{c3::Date}} and {{c3::place}} of collection
    • {{c4::English}}, {{c4::local}}, and {{c4::botanical}} names
    • Name of {{c5::collector}}

• Kew (England)
  • Indian botanical garden, Howrah
  • National botanical research institute, Lucknow

• Storing in preservative
• Dry specimens
• Insects pinned in insect boxes
• Large animals stuffed
• Skeletons
Pair of contrasting features, called a couplet
Actual account of habitat and distribution of plant species found in a particular area
Information for identification of names of species found in a particular area
Contain information on one particular taxon

In {{c1::encystation}}, {{c2::Amoeba}} retracts {{c3::Pseudopodia}} and forms a {{c4::3}}-layered shell around itself
In {{c1::sporulation}}, {{c2::Amoeba}} divides to form many {{c3::pseudopodiospores}}, cell wall bursts and they spread to form adult instances.

Part of botanical garden where large trees are grown in the form of <hl>forests</hl>

Plants - Trees, shrubs, herbs
Animals - Red blood, without red blood
Archaebacteria differ from Eubacteria in having {{c1::different cell wall}}

Archaebacteria

  • Halophiles - {{c1::Salty areas}}
  • Thermoacidophiles - {{c2::Hot Springs}}
  • Methanogens - {{c3::Marshy areas}} and {{c4::Gut of ruminants}}
    • Produce {{c5::methane}} from dung

Cyanobacteria

  • Also called {{c1::blue-green algae}}
  • Have chlorophyll {{c2::α}}
  • Surrounded by {{c3::gelatinous}} sheath
  • Form {{c4::blooms}} in polluted water
  • Have N₂ fixing cells called {{c5::Heterocysts}}
  • Eg. {{c6::Nostoc}}, {{c6::Anabena}}

Diatoms
  • {{c1::Soap box}} structure
  • Walls infused with {{c2::silicon}}
  • Chief {{c3::producer}} in oceans
  • Used in {{c4::polishing and filtration of oils and syrups}}

Dinoflagellates

  • {{c1::Marine}} and {{c2::photosynthetic}}
  • Two {{c3::flagella}}, first {{c3::longitudinally}} and second {{c4::transversely between a furrow in wall plates}}
  • {{c5::Gonyaulax}} is responsible for {{c6::red tide}} and has {{c6::potent toxins}}

Euglenoids

  • {{c1::Freshwater}}, found in {{c1::stagnant}} water
  • Have a flexible protein rich layer called {{c2::pellicle}}
  • Are both {{c3::photosynthetic and heterotrophic}}
  • Pigments identical to {{c4::higher plants}}

Slime Moulds

  • {{c1::Saprophytic}}
  • Form aggregation called {{c2::Plasmodium}} in ideal conditions
  • {{c2::Plasmodium}} bears {{c3::fruiting bodies}} containing {{c3::spores}}
  • {{c3::Spores}} possess {{c4::true walls}}

Protozoans

  • Amoeboid
    • Have {{c1::pseudopodia}}
    • Marine forms have {{c2::silica shells}}
    • Eg. {{c3::Amoeba (Free living)}}, {{c3::Entamoeba (Parasite)}}
  • Flagellated
    • {{c4::Free}} or {{c4::parasitic}}
    • Eg. {{c5::Trypanosoma (Sleeping Sickness)}}
  • Ciliated
    • Have cavity called {{c6::gullet}} which acts as mouth
    • Eg. {{c7::Paramoecium}}
  • Sporozoans
    • Have {{c8::infectious}} spore-like stage
    • Eg. {{c9::Plasmodium}}
Long thread like structures in fungi
Transition phase in fusion where there are two nucleus in cell

Phycomycetes

  • Found in {{c1::aquatic habitats}} and {{c1::decaying wood}}
  • Asexual reproduction: {{c2::zoospores (motile)}} and {{c2::aplanospores (non-motile)}}
  • Mycelium is {{c3::aseptate}} and {{c3::coenocytic}}
  • Eg. {{c4::Mucor}}, {{c4::Rhizopus (Bread Mould)}} and {{c4::Albugo, parasitic fungi on mustard}}

Ascomycetes

  • Mostly {{c1::multi}}cellular
  • Commonly known as {{c2::sac-fungi}}
  • Mycelium {{c3::branched}} and {{c3::septate}}
  • {{c4::Conidiophores}} are asexual spores produced {{c5::exo}}genously on special mycelium
  • Sexual spores are {{c6::ascospores}} which are produced {{c7::endo}}genously in {{c8::asci}}
  • {{c8::Asci}} are arranged in fruiting bodies called {{c9::ascocarps}}
  • {{c10::Neurospora}} is used extensively in biochemical and genetic work.
  • Eg. {{c11::Aspergillus, Claviceps, Neurospora, Penicillium, Morels, Truffles}}

Basidiomycetes

  • Mycelium is {{c1::branched}} and {{c1::septate}}
  • {{c2::Fragmentation}} is asexual reproduction
  • Sex organs are {{c3::absent}}
  • Two cells fuse to form {{c4::basidium}} then do meiosis to form 4 {{c5::basidiospores}}, produced {{c6::exo}}genously
  • {{c4::Basidia}} arranged in fruiting bodies called {{c7::Basidiocarps}}
  • Eg. {{c8::Agaricus (Mushroom), Ustilago (Smut), Puccinia (Rust), puffballs}}

Deuteromycetes

  • Called {{c1::imperfect}} fungi
  • {{c2::Sexual}} form not discovered
  • Get moved to Basidiomycetes and Ascomycetes when {{c2::sexual}} form is discovered
  • Reproduce by asexual spores called {{c3::Conidia}}
  • Mycelium is {{c4::branched}} and {{c4::septate}}
  • Eg. {{c5::Alternaria, Colletotrichum, Trichoderma}}
Viruses have {{c1::inert crystalline}} structure outside of living cell

{{c1::70}} species of algae are edible which include {{c2::Porphyra, Laminaria, Sargassum}}
Agar is obtained from {{c1::Gelidium and Gracilaria}} and is used in {{c2::microbe culture and ice creams and jellies}}
{{c1::Chlorella}} is used as a {{c2::food supplement}} by {{c3::Astronauts}}

Chlorophyceae

  • Called {{c1::green}} algae
  • Have chlorophyll {{c2::a and b}}
  • Chloroplast Shape: {{c3::discoid, plate, reticulate, cup, spiral, ribbon}}
  • Have storage bodies called {{c4::pyrenoids}} which contain {{c5::proteins and starch}}
  • Inner wall {{c6::cellulose}}, Outer wall {{c6::pectose}}
  • Eg. {{c7::Chlamydomonas, Volvox, Ulothrix, Spirogyra, Chara}}

Phaeophycae

  • Called {{c1::brown}} algae
  • Filamentous Brown Algae: {{c2::Ectocarpus}}
  • Branched Brown Algae: {{c3::Kelps}} can reach upto {{c4::100}} meters
  • Possess Chlorophyll {{c5::a, c}}, {{c6::Carotenoids}} and {{c7::Xanthophylls (Fucoxanthin determines color)}}
  • Carbs stored as {{c8::laminarin}} or {{c8::mannitol}}
  • Cell wall covered by gelatinous {{c9::algin}}
  • Structure
    • Held by {{c10::steadfast}}
    • {{c11::Stipe}}
    • Leaflike {{c12::frond}}
  • Asexual Spore: {{c13::Pear-shaped bilfagellate zoospore (Unequal Flagella)}}
  • Gamete: {{c14::Pear-shaped biflagellate}}
  • eg. {{c15::Ectocarpus, Fucus, Dictyota, Laminaria, Sargassum}}

Rhodophyceae

  • Called red algae due to presence of {{c1::r-phycoerythrin}} pigment
  • Stored food is {{c2::floridean starch}}
  • Asexually and Sexually by {{c3::non-motile}} spores and gametes
  • eg. {{c4::Polysiphonia, Porphyra, Gracilaria, Gelidium}}

Bryophyptes are called {{c1::amphibians}} of plant kingdom since they need water to {{c2::reproduce sexually}}
Bryophtes play an important role in {{c1::plant succession}} on bare rocks
Bryophytes are attached to substratum via {{c1::rhizoids}}
Archegonium is {{c1::flask}}-shaped and produces a single egg
Bryophyte zygotes form parasitic {{c1::sporophyte}} which leeches off {{c2::gametophyte}}.

Bryophyte Economic Importance

  • Food for {{c1::herbaceous mammals, birds, etc.}}
  • {{c2::Sphagnum}} provides a fuel called {{c3::peat}} which is also used for {{c4::packaging of living material}} due to high water retaining capacity
  • Decompose rocks and prevent soil erosion

Liverworts

  • Grow in {{c1::moist and shady}} places
  • Plant body is {{c2::thall}}oid
  • Thallus is {{c3::dorsiventral}} and have {{c4::two}} rows of leaves on stem like structures
  • Asexual Reprod
    • {{c5::Fragmentation}}
    • {{c6::Gemmae}}: Asexual buds which grow on {{c6::gemma cups on thallus}}
  • Sporophyte
    • {{c7::Seta}}
    • {{c8::Foot}}
    • {{c9::Capsule}}
  • eg. {{c10::Marchantia, Riccia}}

Mosses

  • 1st stage ({{c1::Protonema}}): Develops from spore, creeping, green, branched and filamentous
  • 2nd stage ({{c2::Leafy}}): Develops from 1st stage as lateral bud, have {{c3::spiral leaves and branched rhizoids}}, bears {{c4::sex organs}}
  • Asexual Reprod: {{c5::Fragmentation and budding}}
  • Zygote becomes sporophyte which has {{c6::foot, seta and capsule::parts}}
  • {{c7::More}} elaborate than liverworts
  • Capsule contains {{c8::haploid spores}}
  • eg. {{c9::Funaria, Polytrichum, Sphagnum}}

Pteridophyta

  • First terrestrial plants to possess {{c1::vascular}} tissues
  • Main Body is {{c2::Sporo}}phyte
  • Leaves
    • Small (microphyll): {{c3::Selaginella}}
    • Large (macrophyll): {{c4::Ferns}}
  • Bear sporangia suspended by leaf-like appendages called {{c5::sporophylls}}, which form {{c6::Strobili}} in {{c7::Selaginella, Equisetum}}
  • Spores give rise to free living small gametophyte called {{c8::prothallus}}
  • Sex organs: {{c9::Antheridium and Archegonium}}
  • {{c10::Antherozoids}} fertilise egg {{c11::internally}}
  • Usually homosporous but heterosporous in {{c12::Selaginella and Salvinia}}
  • Seed habit precursor: {{c13::Embryo development in female gametophyte}}
  • Classes
    • Psilopsida: {{c14::Psilotum}}
    • Lycopsida: {{c15::Selaginella, Lycopodium}}
    • Sphenopsida: {{c16::Equisetum}}
    • Pteropsida: {{c17::Dryopteris, Pteris, Adiantum}}
<center>Gymnosperm {{c1::Giant Redwood Tree}} ({{c2::Seqoia}}) is one of the tallest tree species</center>

Gymnosperm Symbiotes
  • Pinus: {{c1::Mycorhhiza with fungi}}
  • Cycas: {{c2::Coralloid roots with N₂ fixing BGA}}

Gymnosperms

  • {{c1::Hetero}}sporous - {{c3::Macro}}sporangium and {{c4::Micro}}sporangium
  • Born on sporophyte clusters called {{c2::strobili}}
  • Monoecious: {{c5::Pinus}}
  • Dioecious: {{c6::Cycas}}
  • MMC divides meiotically to form 4 {{c7::megaspores}}, one grows to 2 or more {{c8::archegonia}}
  • {{c9::Non-covered}} seeds
  • {{c10::Naked}} ovule

Angiosperms

  • Pollen grains and ovules are covered by {{c1::flowers}}
  • Seeds are enclosed by {{c2::fruits}}
  • Smallest: {{c3::Wolffia}}
  • Largest: {{c4::Eucylaptus}}

Plant Life Cycles

  • Haplontic
    • Sporophyte: {{c1::Zygote which instantly divides}}
    • Gametophyte: Dominant
    • eg. {{c2::Most Algae (Volvox, Spirogyra, Chlamydomonas)}}
  • Diplontic
    • Sporophyte: Dominant
    • Gametophyte: {{c3::Gametes}}
    • eg. {{c4::Gymnosperms, Angiosperms, Algae (Fucus)}}
  • Haplo-Diplontic
    • Haplontic-Leaning: {{c5::Algae (Ectocarpus, Polysiphonia), Bryophytes}}
    • Diplontic-Leaning: {{c6::Pteridophytes}}

Porifera Structure

Pores called {{c1::ostia}} meet central cavity called {{c2::spongocoel}} and exit via {{c3::osculum}}

Coelentrata have {{c1::8}} rows of comb plates
Annelida have {{c1::paired ganglia}} for a neural system

Mollusca have {{c1::skin}} above hump and have {{c2::gills}} between them

Chordata essential features

  • {{c1::Noto}}chord present
  • CNS is {{c2::dorsal, hollow and single}}
  • {{c3::Pharynx}} is perforated by {{c4::gill slits}}
  • Heart is {{c5::ventral}}
  • {{c6::Post-anal}} tail is present

Chordates

SubphylumNotochord
Urochordata{{c1::Only in larval tail}}
CephalochordataThroughout life, head to tail
VertebrataReplaced by bony/cartilaginous vertebral column

Vertebrata characteristics

  • Heart with {{c1::2/3/4}} chambers
  • {{c2::Kidneys}} for excretion
  • {{c3::Paired}} appendages

Cyclostomata

  • {{c1::6-15}} gill slits
  • Mouth: {{c2::Circular}} without jaws
  • Devoid of {{c3::scales}}
  • Cranium and vertebral column are {{c4::cartilaginous}}
  • Migrate from {{c5::marine habitat}} to {{c5::freshwater}} to lay eggs and die

Chondricthyes

  • Notochord is {{c1::persistent::duration of stay}}
  • Gill slits {{c2::separate}} and without {{c3::operculum}}
  • Tough skin with {{c4::placoid}} scales
  • Teeth are modified backwards {{c5::placoid scales}}
  • Need to swim constantly to avoid sinking
  • {{c6::Poikilo}}thermous
  • Male pelvic fins have {{c7::claspers}}
  • {{c8::Vivi}}parous

Osteichthyes

  • {{c1::Bony}} endoskeleton
  • {{c2::4}} pairs of gills covered by {{c3::operculum}}
  • Skin covered by {{c4::cycloid}}/{{c5::ctenoid}} scales
  • {{c6::Air bladder}} present which regulates buoyancy
  • {{c7::Ovi}}parous

Amphibia

  • Body: {{c1::Head}} and {{c1::trunk}}
  • {{c2::Tympanum}} acts as ear
  • {{c3::Cloaca}} is alimentary canal, urinary and reproductive tracts combined
  • Respiration mediums: {{c4::Skin}}, {{c4::Lungs}}, {{c4::Gills}}
  • {{c5::Ovi}}parous

Reptilia

  • Origin: {{c1::Reptum (Latin) - To crawl}}
  • {{c2::Dry}} and {{c2::cornified}} skin, has epidermal {{c3::scales}}/{{c3::scutes}}
  • {{c4::Tympanum}} acts as ear
  • {{c5::Poikilo}}therms and {{c6::Ovi}}parous
  • {{c7::Internal}} fertilisation

Aves

  • {{c1::Feathers}} present on skin
  • {{c2::Beak}} on mouth
  • Forelimbs modified into {{c3::wings}}
  • Oil glands at {{c4::base of tail}}
  • Long bones are {{c5::hollow}} ({{c5::Pneumatic}})
  • {{c6::4}} chamber heart
  • {{c7::Homeo}}thermous
  • {{c8::Air sacs}} are connected to lungs to {{c9::supplement respiration}}

Leaf
  • {{c1::Lateral flattened}} structure borne on node
  • Bears bud on axil (Base) called {{c2::axillary bud}}
  • Arranged {{c4::acro}}petally

Leaf structure
  • Parts
    • {{c1::Leaf Base}}
    • {{c2::Petiole}}
    • {{c3::Lamina}}
  • {{c1::Leaf base}} may bear two appendages called {{c4::stipules}}
  • {{c1::Leaf base}} becomes a sheath in {{c5::monocots}}
  • {{c6::Legumes}} have swollen {{c1::leaf bases}} called {{c7::pulvinus}}
  • {{c8::Midrib}}: Middle prominent vein

Simple Leaf: {{c1::Single}} lamina on petiole
Compund Leaf: {{c1::Multiple}} lamina on petiole

Phyllotaxy

  • Alternate
    • {{c1::One leaf}} at each node
    • eg. {{c2::China Rose}}
  • Opposite
    • {{c3::Two leaves}} at each node
    • eg. {{c4::Guava}}
  • Whorled
    • {{c5::Several leaves}} at each node
    • eg. {{c6::Alstonia}}
Arrangement of flowers on floral axis

Inflorescence
  • Racemose: {{c1::Main axis continues to grow}}
  • Cymose: {{c2::Main axis terminates in a flower}}

Symmetry

Ovary Position

  • Epigynous
    • Ovary {{c5::at bottom}} ({{c5::Inferior}})

Fabaceae

  • Previously called {{c1::Papillonaceae}}
  • Subfamily of {{c2::Leguminosae}}
  • Vegetative Characters
    • Stem: {{c3::Erect or climber}}
    • Leaves: {{c4::Pinnate alternate}}
    • Leaf Base: {{c5::Pulvinate}}
    • Venation: {{c6::Reticulate}}
    • Stipules: {{c7::Stipulate}}
  • Floral Characteristics
    • Inflorescence: {{c8::Racemose}}
    • Flower: {{c9::Bisexual Zygomorphic}}
    • Calyx: {{c10::5 sepals, Valvate/Imbricate}}
    • Corolla: {{c11::5 petals, Polypetalous, Vexillary}}
    • Androecium: {{c12::10, Diadelphous, Dithecous}}
    • Gynoecium: {{c13::Superior, Monocarpellary, Marginal Placentation}}
    • Fruit: {{c14::Legume}}

      {{c15::% ⚧ K(5) C1+2+(2) A(9)+1 G1}}

  • Also called {{c1::Calvin}} cycle
  • First product is {{c2::PGA}} ({{c2::3}} C)

  • Reduction:
    {{c8::2ATP + 2NADPH + 3-PGA}} → {{c9::Triose Phosphate}}
  • Regeneration:
    {{c10::ATP + Triose Phosphate}} → {{c11::RuBP + CO2 + H2O}}
  • {{c12::2}} NADPH2 and {{c13::3}} ATP is utilised for 1 Carbon fixed
  • {{c12::12}} NADPH2 and {{c13::18}} ATP is utilised for 1 Glucose fixed

Muscle contraction mechanism

  • Sliding of {{c1::thin}} filaments over {{c1::thick}} filaments
  • Action potential causes {{c2::Ca2+}} ions release into {{c3::sarcoplasm}}
  • {{c2::Ca2+}} ions bind with {{c4::troponin}} and demask {{c5::actin binding sites}}
  • Myosin uses {{c6::ATP}} to {{c7::bind to actin}} and forms a {{c8::cross-bridge}}
  • Actin filaments are pulled to {{c9::A-band}} and {{c10::Z-line}} shortens, thus causing contraction
  • Thus, {{c11::I-bands}} shorten and {{c12::A-bands}} retain length
  • Myosin filament debinds and relaxes back into normal state

  • {{c1::Origin of replication}}
  • {{c2::Selectable marker}}
  • {{c3::Cloning sites}}
  • {{c4::Vectors}}

Selectable markers

Help to {{c1::eliminate non-transformants}}
    Resistance markers:
  • A{{c2::mpicilin}}
  • C{{c3::hloramphecinol}}
  • T{{c4::etracycline}}
  • K{{c5::anamycin}}
Normal E. coli has {{c6::zero}} resistance

Cloning sites

    E. coli vector pBR332
  • Ampicilin: {{c1::PvuI, PstI}}
  • Tetracycline: {{c2::BamHI, SalI}}
  • Rop: {{c3::PvuII}}
BamHI changes {{c4::Tetracycline}} resistance so that transformants survive in {{c4::Ampicilin}} but not {{c4::Tetracycline}}

β-galactosidase gives {{c5::blue}} color, thus transformant colonies are {{c6::colorless}} and non-transformant colonies are {{c7::blue}}.

Vectors

  • Agrobacterium tumifaciens
    • Delivers {{c1::T-DNA}} to make {{c2::plant}} cells into {{c3::tumors}}
    • {{c4::Ti plasmid}} has been modified into a cloning vector
  • {{c5::Retroviruses}} in Animals

Inserting DNA

  • Cells are made competent for insertion via:
    • Treatment with {{c1::Ca2+}}
    • Cooling, Heating to {{c2::42}}°C ({{c3::Heat Shock}}) and cooling again
  • Gene gun
    • Also called {{c4::biolistics}}
    • Used in {{c5::plants}}
    • {{c6::Gold and Tungsten}} particles coated with DNA are bombarded
  • Vectors
  • Micro-injection: Directly to cytoplasm in {{c7::Animal}} cells

Isolation of DNA

  • Cell wall breakdown
    • Bacteria- {{c1::Lysozyme}}
    • Plant- {{c2::Cellulase}}
    • Fungus- {{c3::Chitinase}}
  • RNA- {{c4::Ribonuclease}}
  • Protein- {{c5::Protease}}
  • DNA is precipitated by adding {{c6::chilled ethanol}}
Usage of rod to remove DNA

Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR)

  • Uses {{c1::primers}} to {{c2::replicate strands}}
  • DNA Segment can be amplified upto {{c3::1 billion}} times
  • Thermostable DNA Polymerase is used which is extracted from {{c4::Thermus aquaticus}} bacteria
  • Process
    • {{c5::Denaturation}}
    • {{c6::Annealing}}
    • {{c7::Extension}}
Protein expressed by a protein expressing gene in a recombinant host

Bioreactors

  • {{c1::100-1000}} L volume
  • Most common: {{c2::Stirring}} type
  • Has {{c3::cylindrical/curved}} base
  • Systems used:
    • {{c4::Agitator system}}
    • {{c5::O2 delivery system}}
    • {{c6::Foam control system}}
    • {{c7::Temperature control system}}
    • {{c8::pH control system}}
    • {{c9::Sampling Port}}

3 critical research areas in biotechnology
  • Providing {{c1::best catalyst}}
  • {{c2::Optimal}} conditions
  • {{c3::Downstream}} processing

Genetically Modified Organisms

  • More tolerant crops to {{c1::abiotic stresses}}
  • Reduced reliance on {{c2::chemical pssticides}}
  • Reduce {{c3::post-harvest losses}}
  • Efficient {{c4::mineral}} usage
  • Enhanced {{c5::nutritional}} value

Bt Cotton

  • Bt Toxins kill:
    • Lepidopterans: {{c1::Tobacco Budworms}}
    • Coleopterans: {{c2::Beetles}}
    • Dipterans: {{c3::Flies and Mosquitoes}}
  • Mechanism
    • {{c4::Bacillus thuringenesis}} forms insecticidal {{c5::protein crystals}}
    • They get activated in {{c6::alkaline gut of insects}}
    • Toxin binds to {{c7::midgut epithelial cells}}, causing lysis and death
  • Bt cotton genes
    • Cotton Bollworm: {{c8::CryIAc, CryIIAb}}
    • Corn Borer: {{c9::CryIAb}}
Bt Cotton, Corn, Rice, Tomato, Potato, Soyabean

RNA Interference

  • Silences (Prevents translation) of mRNA due to {{c1::dsRNA}} which binds to it
  • Can be from {{c2::RNA viruses}} or {{c3::Transposons (Mobile genetic elements)}}
  • Used in {{c4::tobacco}} against {{c5::nematodes}}
  • {{c6::Sense and Antisense}} RNA are produced which silence mRNA
{{c1::30}} recombinant therapeutics are approved globally and {{c2::12}} are approved for sale in India

Insulin

  • Used to cure {{c1::Diabetes Mellitus}}
  • Earlier, extracted from {{c2::pigs and cattle}}
  • Pre-mature Insulin (Pro-hormone)
    • {{c3::C peptide}}
    • Mature Insulin
      • {{c4::A}} & {{c4::B}} chains, held by {{c5::Sulphide Linkages}}
  • {{c3::C peptide}} is removed upon maturation
  • In 1983, {{c6::Eli Lilly}}, an {{c7::American}} company produced {{c4::A}} & {{c4::B}} chains via {{c8::E. coli}}

Gene Therapy

  • Correction of a {{c1::Gene Defect}}
  • First Clinical Gene Therapy was done in 1990 on a 4 year old girl with {{c2::ADA}} deficiency
  • In {{c2::ADA}} Deficiency, {{c3::Adenosine deaminase}} gene is deleted
  • Temporarily cured by {{c4::bone marrow transplantation}} and {{c5::enzyme therapy}}
  • Process
    • {{c6::Lymphocytes}} are extracted
    • {{c7::cDNA}} is inserted
    • {{c6::Lymphocytes}} are reintroduced
  • Can be permanently cured if therapy is done in {{c8::embryo}} stage

Molecular Diagnosis

  • PCR
    • Detects {{c1::low}} concentration of pathogens
    • Detects {{c2::mutations for cancer}} and {{c2::HIV}}
  • Recombinant DNA Technology
    • Single RNA/DNA having {{c3::radioactive}} molecules which undergo autoradiography
    • If gene is mutated there is {{c4::no effect}}
  • ELISA
    • {{c5::Antigen-antibody}} interaction

Transgenic Animals

  • Possess {{c1::foreign gene}}
  • {{c2::Physiology and Development}}: Working of animals
  • Study of Disease: Models have been made for {{c3::Cancer, Cystic fibrosis, Rheumatoid arthritis, Alzheimer's}}
  • Biological Products
    • Human Protein {{c4::1-α-antitrypsis}} treats {{c5::emphysema}}
    • First transgenic cow: {{c6::Rosie}}
    • Produces α-lactalbumin rich milk ({{c7::2.4}}g/L) which is more suitable for babies
  • Vaccine Safety
    • Transgenic Mice: {{c8::Polio}} vaccine
  • Chemical Safety
    • Made to be more sensitive to toxic substances

Ethical Issues

{{c1::Genetic Engineering Approval Committee::Organisation}} debates on GM Research
  • Biopiracy
    • Use of bioresources via approval
    • {{c2::2nd}} amendment of {{c2::Indian Patents}} Bill takes this into consideration
  • Rice
    • {{c3::200,000}} varieties in India
    • {{c4::27}} varieties of Basmati
    • In 1997, a US company patented Basmati by crossing it with a {{c5::semi-dwarf}} variety
    • Same thing was done for {{c6::turmeric and neem}}
The crops engineered for <hl>glyphosate</hl> are genetically resistant to

<hl>{{c1::Flavr savr}}</hl> variety of tomato remains fresh for a
longer period than normal tomato due to silencing of gene coding for enzyme <hl>{{c2::polygalacturonase}}</hl>

Exponential Growth Model

  • Formula: {{c1::Nt = N0ert}}
  • r values:
    • Norway rat: {{c2::0.015}}
    • Flour beetle: {{c3::0.12}}
    • India Population: {{c4::0.0205}}

Logistic Growth Model

  • Mainly used model is {{c1::Verhulst-Pearl logistic growth}}
{{c2::\[\frac{dN}{dt}=rN(1-\frac{N}{K})\]}}
  • K is {{c3::carrying capacity}}

Life history variation

  • Breed once in life: {{c1::Pacific Salmon Fish, Bamboo}}
  • Many times in life: {{c2::Most birds and Mammals}}
  • Large number of small offspring: {{c3::Oysters, Pelagic fishes}}
  • Small number of large offspring: {{c4::Birds, Mammals}}

Population Interactions

Species ASpecies BName
{{c1::+}}{{c1::+}}{{c2::Mutualism}}
{{c3::-}}{{c3::-}}{{c4::Competition}}
{{c5::+}}{{c5::-}}{{c6::Predation, Parasitism}}
{{c7::+}}{{c7::0}}{{c8::Commensalism}}
{{c9::-}}{{c9::0}}{{c10::Amensalism}}
In {{c1::predation, parasitism and commensalism}}, interacting species live closely together

Physiological Adaptations

  • High Altitude Humans
    • Increased {{c1::RBC}} production
    • Decreases {{c2::binding affinity for Hb}}
    • Increases {{c3::breathing}} rate
  • Archaebacteria carry out metabolism at temperatures greater than {{c4::100}}°C
  • Antarctic fish live in {{c5::subzero}} waters
  • A large variety of invertebrates and fish live in pressures {{c6::100}} times that of atmospheric pressure

Behavioral Adaptation

  • Desert lizards {{c1::bask in sun}} in {{c2::low temperature}} and {{c1::hide in shade}} in {{c2::high temperature}}
  • Some species {{c3::burrow into ground}} to escape heat
Tiger census in National Parks and Reserves is based on {{c1::pug marks and fecal pellets}}
Mammals from colder climates have shorter ears and limbs to minimize heat loss
Genetically fixed modification to help survive in a habitat, generally developed over a lot of time

Morphological Adaptations

  • Kangaroo Rat
    • In {{c1::North American Desert}}
    • Obtains water via {{c2::internal fat oxidation}}
    • {{c3::Concentrated}} urine
  • Desert Plants
    • Thick {{c4::cuticle}}
    • Sunken {{c5::stomata}}
    • {{c6::CAM}} photosynthesis
    • Leaves are {{c7::spines}}, stem is used for photosynthesis

Predation

  • {{c1::Moth}} on {{c2::Prickly Pear Cactus}} in {{c3::Australia}}
  • {{c4::Pisasters}} in {{c5::American Pacific coast}}
  • {{c6::25}}% of insects are {{c7::phytophagous}}
  • Prevention
    • Acacia, Opuntia: {{c8::Thorns}}
    • Calotropis: {{c9::Poisonous Cardiac Glycosides}}

Competition

  • {{c1::Flamingoes}} and {{c1::fishes}} over {{c2::zooplankton}} in {{c3::South American Lakes}}
  • {{c4::Abingdon Tortoise}} and {{c4::Goats}} over grass in {{c5::Galapagos Islands}}
  • {{c6::Balanus}} over {{c6::Chathamalus}} in {{c7::Scotland}}

Parasitism

  • Liverfluke in {{c1::Humans}} as primary hosts and {{c2::Snails and Fishes}} as secondary hosts
  • Ectoparasites
    • Humans: {{c3::Lice}}
    • Dogs: {{c4::Ticks}}
    • Fish: {{c5::Copepods}}
    • Plants: {{c6::Cuscuta}}
  • Brood Parasitism
    • {{c7::Host incubates parasite eggs}}
    • eg. {{c8::Cuckoo to Crow}}

Mutualism

  • Fungi and Plants: {{c1::Lichens and Mycorrhiza}}
  • Fig & Wasps: Some seeds are used as {{c2::food for larvae}}
  • Orchids ({{c3::Ophrys}}) petals look like {{c4::female wasps}}

Regulate Response

  • eg. {{c1::All birds, mammals and a few lower species}}
  • Regulate body via {{c2::physiological and behavioral}} changes like {{c3::body temperature and osmotic concentration}}
  • eg. in humans, {{c4::Shivering}} below 37°C and {{c4::sweating}} above it

Conform Response

  • Body environment is same as {{c1::ambient}}
  • Heat loss/Mass ∝ {{c2::Surface Area/Mass}}, thus {{c3::small}} animals lose heat faster and are rarely found in {{c4::polar}} regions.
  • eg. {{c5::99% of Animals, all Plants}}

Migrate Response

  • {{c1::Move to different area}} upon stressful conditions
  • {{c2::Keolado}} National Park hosts {{c3::Siberian birds}} in {{c4::Winter}}

Suspend Response

  • Bacteria, Fungi, Algae: {{c1::Spores}}
  • Higher Plants: {{c2::Seed Dormancy}}
  • Animals
    • {{c3::Bears}} undergo {{c4::hibernation}} in {{c5::winter}}
    • {{c6::Snails and fishes}} undergo {{c7::aestivation}} in {{c8::summer}}
    • Zooplankton: {{c9::Diapause}}, {{c10::Development}} is halted

Survival Factors

  • Temperature
    • Most important factor
    • Eurythermal: Handles {{c1::wide}} temperature range
    • Stenothermal: Handles {{c1::narrow}} temperature range
  • Salinity
    • Inland: {{c2::5}} particles per 1000
    • Sea: {{c3::30-35}} particles per 1000
    • Hypersaline Lagoons: {{c4::>100}} particles per 1000
    • Euryhaline: {{c5::Wide}} salinity range
    • Stenohaline: {{c5::Narrow}} salinity range
  • Light
    • Closely linked with temperature on surface
  • Soil
    • Soil Composition
    • Grain Size
    • Aggregation

Mutualism but not obligate
Red/Yellow billed Ox-pecker and Black Rhinoceros
Crocodile bird (Plover) and Crocodile
Sea anemone and hermit crab

By Gause
Two closely related species competing for same resources cannot co-exist indefinitely and inferior one will be eliminated

Competitive co-existence principle


  • {{c1::Five}} closely related species of {{c2::warblers}} by changing foraging pattern (Documented by {{c3::Mac Arthur}})
  • {{c4::Darwin}} found that {{c5::fourteen}} species of {{c6::finches}} co-exist in Galapagos Islands

Amensalism

  • Inhibitng organism is called {{c1::Amensal}}
  • Penicillium secretes penicillin which kills bacteria
  • Streptomyces inhibit growth of bacteria
  • {{c2::Juglans nigra}} ({{c2::Black Walnut}}) secretes {{c3::Juglone}} which is toxic to apple, alfalfa
  • {{c4::Convolvulus arvensis}} inhibits growth of {{c5::wheat}}
Study of structure and function of nature

In <hl>colder climate</hl>, some fishes possess <hl>larger</hl> size with <hl>larger vertebrae size</hl>

Phenotype variables due to environment fluctuation
Range is called phenotypic plasticity

Ecological selection of organisms having high r value
  • High fecundity
  • Small body size
  • Early maturity
  • Short generation time
  • Wide offspring dispersion
eg. Bacteria, Diatoms, Insects, Weeds, Rodents

Selection based on high K value
  • Large body size
  • Long life expectancy
  • Production of fewer offspring
eg. Elephants, Humans, Whales, Arctic Terns
